results.title: Asep in action: the teacher (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Contains interviews with teachers on their reactions to A.S.E.P.. They discuss the applicability of A.S.E.P. courses for slow learners through to above average learners. Discusses problems of obtaining the necessary materials and the time required in preparation, followed by demonstrations of the course in classroom situations.

results.title: Asep in action: the student (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows students using the unit “Plants” in the classroom and on an excursion, emphasizing the practical aspects of A.S.E.P. courses, whilst participating in excursions, they discus teacher/student relationships, and their feelings about group work and electives.

results.title: Ascot: a race against time
results.creator_credit: James Carr, World Wide and Wimpey Organization
results.brief_description: The building of the new Queen Elizabeth II Grandstand at Ascot in record time, and an account of the work which was involved. Ten months was the scheduled time allowed for the builders to replace the old Grand Tier - ten months of close co-operation between client, architect, engineer and construction team. Great use of archival footage giving a sense of history and interesting juxtaposition between the models of the new Ascot and its actual construction.

results.title: As our boyhood is...
results.brief_description: A documentary which studies the facilities for education - both good and bad - available to Afro-American children in the southern states of the USA during the mid-1940’s. An interesting documentary for its time for its sympathetic attitude towards the plight of Afro-American children in getting an education. Photography by Roger Barlow and Jospeh Braun.

results.title: As others see us: a look at interpersonal relations
results.creator_credit: Monte Young and Salenger Educational Media
results.brief_description: An animated film which examines self-image by feedback; exploring the reasons why people see us differently from how we see ourselves. Provides examples of how relationships can be improved by openness and how to obtain positive feedback to enhance effective communication and interpersonal relationships.

results.title: As old as the hills
results.brief_description: A history of oil from dinosaur days to the sinking of a present-day oil well. Shows how oil was formed over one hundred million years ago as a result of the decomposition of marine and plant life, and explains how rock movements over the ages have trapped the oil in porous layers in the earth’s crust.

results.title: As is
results.creator_credit: Iris Merlis, Brandman Productions, Interchange Television Group and Michael Lindsay-Hogg
results.brief_description: Based on a play by William M. Hoffman, this made for television feature length film was originally produced for Broadway by The Circle Repertory Company and The Glines. Reflective, confronting, compassionate, and experimental in treatment and language “As is” deals up-front with the issue of AIDS in its early days, documenting the different phases from all angles, from the victim through to the lover, the friends, the family and the health carers. Through a montage of scenes, multi-layered, past and present, we witness the story of Rich (Robert Carradine), a Manhattan-based writer who discovers he has a pre-AIDS condition, subsequently finding himself being ostracised by one and all. Alienated and surrounded by fear and paranoia Rich has to mentally come to terms with AIDS and the ignorance which exists amongst the general population, including the medical fraternity, about this new disease. His friend and ex-lover Saul (Jonathan Hadary) is there to support Rich through the emotional stages of fear, anger, denial, cynicism, death vs the will to live, and finally, acceptance. Colleen Dewhurst is outstanding as the hospice worker who through her monologues to the camera tells us what it’s like caring for AIDS patients, her emotional attachments and her anger and frustration with this disease called AIDS. Although acted and directed in a theatrical style, “As is” still is an exceptional film, informative and compassionate, and particularly interesting from an historical viewpoint. Cast also includes Joanna Miles, Allan Scarfe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Iris Merlis, Brandman Productions, Interchange Television Group and Michael Lindsay-Hogg
